grammar_notes: Conditional of 'querer' (to want) - very polite form
cultural_note: Much more polite than 'quero' (I want). Portuguese value politeness highly!
tip: Always use 'queria' instead of 'quero' when ordering
example_en: I would like a coffee please.

grammar_notes: Literally 'can I have' - polite request form
cultural_note: Alternative to 'queria' - both are very polite
tip: Another polite way to request - interchangeable with queria

mnemonic: PARA MIM = 'PAH-rah MEEM' - parrot says 'for ME!'
grammar_notes: Preposition + stressed pronoun - used after prepositions
cultural_note: Point to yourself slightly when saying 'para mim' - natural gesture
tip: Mim (not me/eu) after prepositions - important grammar!

cultural_note: In Portugal always 'ementa' - saying 'cardápio' marks you as Brazilian

mnemonic: PRATO sounds like 'PLATE' - the plate of the day!
grammar_notes: Masculine - 'o prato'. Often great value at restaurants!
cultural_note: Usually the best value - fresh ingredients bought that day
tip: Usually good value at restaurants and uses fresh ingredients
example_pt: Qual é o prato do dia?
example_en: What is the dish of the day?

mnemonic: CONTA = 'COUNT' - count up what you owe!
grammar_notes: Feminine noun. Ask for it when ready to pay
cultural_note: In Portugal servers won't bring the bill until asked - not rude just different!
tip: In Portugal you must ask for the bill - they won't rush you

mnemonic: MAIS ALGUMA COISA = 'My-sh AL-GOOMA COYZA' - more of something?
cultural_note: Servers ask this before bringing the bill - standard service
tip: Waiter will often ask this before getting the bill

mnemonic: É TUDO = 'A TOO-DOO' - that's the whole to-do list!
cultural_note: Polite way to indicate you've finished ordering
tip: Say this when you've finished ordering - simple and clear

grammar_notes: Question form. Often about service charge or specific items
cultural_note: Tips not expected in Portugal but service charge sometimes added
tip: Ask about service charge or items like bread (couvert)

mnemonic: BICA = 'BEEKA' - the coffee BEAMS into your cup!
grammar_notes: Lisbon slang for espresso. Feminine noun
cultural_note: Lisbon says 'bica' Porto says 'cimbalino' - regional difference!

mnemonic: GALÃO = 'GALLON' - a big gallon of milky coffee!
grammar_notes: Masculine noun. Large milky coffee served in a tall glass
cultural_note: Much bigger than American latte - served in a tall glass
tip: Large milky coffee in a glass - bigger than typical latte
distractors: uma meia de leite;um café;uma bica

mnemonic: MEIA DE LEITE = 'HALF of MILK' - half and half!
grammar_notes: Feminine. Smaller milky coffee in a cup (not glass)
cultural_note: Like a cappuccino but Portuguese style - half espresso half milk
tip: Smaller milky coffee in a cup - like a small latte
distractors: um galão;um café com leite;uma bica
